subject: Religion & Spirituality
title: Orthodox Christianity: The Forgotten Branch
description: A quick, practical guide to Orthodox Christianity: The Forgotten Branch.

hook.text: Most people know Catholic and Protestant. But 300 million Christians belong to a third branch most Westerners forget.

buildup.text: In 1054, Christianity split East and West. The Eastern Orthodox Church kept ancient traditions the West abandoned.

discovery.text: Orthodox worship uses icons, incense, and chanting. Services last three hours. The aesthetic is deliberately mystical.

twist.text: The Orthodox Church has no single pope. Each national church is self-governing, united by shared theology.

climax.text: From Russia to Greece to Ethiopia, Orthodoxy quietly thrives. It's Christianity's oldest continuous tradition.

punchline.text: Orthodox Christianity: the oldest branch most people have never explored.

quiz.question: When did the Eastern Orthodox Church split from Catholicism?
